titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Blanche Lazzell Papers, 1893-1956, bulk 1901-1940, in the Archives of American Art AAA.lazzblan
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rihoko Ueno
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by Leslie J. and Johanna Garfield.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 210040

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-03-03T10:42-0500

did.abstract: The papers of printmaker, etcher, and painter Blanche Lazzell (1878-1956) measure 4.6 linear feet and date from 1893 to 1986, with the bulk of the material dating from 1901 to 1940. Found within the papers are biographical materials; correspondence with family, friends, and colleagues; writings; five diaries; scattered personal business records; printed material; artwork; photographs; and artifacts.
did.langmaterial: Collection is in English and French.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 9 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1894-1970 (0.3 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 5: Personal Business Records, 1894-1916 (0.1 linear feet; Box 3)
Series 6: Printed Material, 1899-1986 (1 linear feet; Box 3-4)
Series 8: Photographic Material, 1897-1956 (0.5 linear feet; Box 5-6)
Series 9: Artifacts, circa 1910-1956 (0.1 linear feet; Box 6)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Blanche Lazzell (1878-1956) was a printmaker, etcher, painter, and rug designer who worked primarily in Provincetown, Massachusetts and Morgantwon, West Virginia.

Nettie Blanche Lazzell was born in Maidsville, West Virginia, in 1878, the daughter of Mary Prudence Pope and Cornelius Carhart Lazzell. At some point during her childhood, Lazzell became partially deaf. When Lazzell was fifteen, she enrolled in the West Virginia Conference Seminary, now West Virginia Wesleyan College and graduated in 1898.

In 1899, Lazzell continued her studies at the South Carolina Co-educational Institute and graduated that same year. She later matriculated into the West Virginia University (1901-1905) where she took drawing and art history classes with William J. Leonard and earned a degree in fine arts. After graduation, Lazzell periodically studied at the university until 1909. Lazzell moved to New York City in 1907 and enrolled in the Art Students League of New York in 1908 where she studied under William Merritt Chase.

Lazzell travelled to Europe during the summer of 1912. After visiting several cities, Lazzell went to Paris and stayed beyond the tour to attend classes at the Académie Julian and the Académie Moderne where she studied with painter Charles Guérin. Lazzell returned to the United States in the fall of 1913 and stayed in West Virginia with her sister Bessie. She held a solo exhibition of her sketches and paintings in 1914. Lazzell moved to the thriving art colony at Provincetown, Massachusetts in 1915. There, she studied with Charles Webster Hawthorne, who founded the Cape Cod School of Art, and Oliver Chaffee, who taught her the technique for white-line woodcuts. Lazzell quickly adopted and excelled at making white-line woodblock prints, joined the Provincetown Printers, an art collective, and regularly exhibited with them.

n 1918, Lazzell converted an "old fish house" overlooking the Provincetown harbor into her studio and summer home. She planted a lush garden that became a tourist attraction where she often hosted teas and taught classes on painting and woodblock printing. The studio became her primary summer residence, though she often returned to Morgantown, West Virginia. Lazzell also visited other artist colonies during this time, including one in Woodstock, New York where she studied with Andrew Dasburg.

In 1919 Lazzell was featured in an exhibition at Touchstone Gallery in New York City. Later that year, the Provincetown Printers were featured at the Detroit Institute of Arts exhibition "Wood Block Prints in Color by American Artists". That show included Lazzell's depiction of the Monongahela River in Morgantown.

From 1923 to 1924, Lazzell travelled again to Europe and studied with Fernand Legér, André Lhote, and Albert Gleizes in Paris. Lazzell studied Cubism and took a class with Gleizes and her work became more abstract. When she returned to Provincetown, she had her studio rebuilt so it was more comfortable during the winter. She continued to teach art at her studio and participate in exhibitions.

In addition to her woodblock prints, Lazzell also worked with batik, rug design, and hand-painted china. She was a member of numerous arts organizations such as the Société Anonyme, New York Society of Women Artists, Provincetown Art Association, the Sail Loft Club (a Provincetown women's art club), and the Society of Independent Artists. In 1934, Lazzell received a Federal Art Project grant through the Works Progress Administration and created a mural titled Justice for the Morgantown courthouse.
Lazzell died in Morgantown, West Virginia in 1956.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Blanche Lazzell papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: The papers were originally loaned for microfilming on reels 2988-2991 and most of them, but not all, were included in a later donation. The papers not included in the later donation are only available on microfilm.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: The collection was microfilmed on 35 mm microfilm reels 2988-2991, available at Archives of American Art offices and through interlibrary loan. Researchers are advised that the filmed order does not reflect the current order of the collection as described in this finding aid.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Blanche Lazzell papers were anonymously donated to the Archives of American Art in 1987, including most of the materials that had been earlier loaned for microfilming in 1983.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Blanche Lazzell papers, 1893-1986, bulk 1901-1940. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection was fully processed by Rihoko Ueno in October 2014 with funding provided by Leslie J. and Johanna Garfield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of printmaker, etcher, and painter Blanche Lazzell (1878-1956) measure 4.6 linear feet and date from 1893 to 1986, with the bulk of the material dating from 1901 to 1940. Found within the papers are biographical materials; correspondence with family, friends, and colleagues; writings; five diaries; scattered personal business records; printed material; artwork; photographs; and artifacts.
Biographical material includes school report cards, address books, obituaries, membership certificates, and travel documents from Blanche Lazzell's travels abroad in Europe.

Correspondence is with family, friends, and colleagues. Family correspondence is predominately with Lazzell's sisters, and a lesser amount with her brother Rufus and other relatives. Well over one-half of the correspondence is with friends and colleagues, including Arthur Lee Post and John O' Connor, and one or more letters from Oliver Chaffee, Andrew Dasburg, Robert Henri, and Ralph M. Pearson, among others.

Writings include notebooks, essays, and notes. Notebooks are primarily class notes, including one from Lazzells's studies in France during her second trip to Europe, and another maintained as a record of artwork. Also found are essays,including one about Provincetown; notes; biographical sketches; and lists of exhibitions and artwork. Five diaries document the late 1890s and Lazzell's trips to Europe in 1912-1913 and 1923-1924.

Scattered personal business records consist of 3 expense account ledgers and one sales ledger. Printed Material includes guest books, news clippings, exhibition catalogs, exhibition announcements, magazines, brochures, and newsletters. Artwork includes pencil drawings and sketches, mostly from studies with the artist Albert Gleizes in Paris. Photographic material consists of photographs, slides, and one lantern slide. The photographs are of Blanche Lazzell with artists and friends, her studio and the harbor in Provincetown, artwork, and travels in Italy.
Artifacts include 2 metal signs and 1 paint palette in a metal case.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Portions of the microfilmed material were retained by the donor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical material includes school report cards from West Virginia Conference Seminary and West Virginia University, 2 address books, obituaries, membership certificates, and assorted travel documents from Blanche Lazzell's trips to Europe.

did.unittitle: West Virginia Conference Seminary Report Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is with family members, friends, and colleagues.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as 2 subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Lazzell's family correspondence is with her sisters on the subject of daily life, experiences, and travels. There is also additional scattered correspondence with her brother Rufus and other relatives, such as her niece Frances Reed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The correspondence with Lazzell's sisters are grouped together at the beginning of the series and arranged chronologically. The letters with her sisters were not alphabetized since they were frequently addressed "Dear Sister" and did not specify the recipient's name, though Lazzell often wrote to her younger sister Bessie. The rest of the subseries is arranged alphabetically, starting with an aunt and uncle who are only given nicknames.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Barkis" is probably an uncle. The nickname is from David Copperfield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of the correspondence with friends is with Arthur Lee Pos. Additional scattered correspondence is with friends and colleages, including artists Oliver Chaffee, Andrew Dasburg, Robert Henri, and Ralph M. Pearson, among others. There is also limited correspondence with museums and art organizations, such as the Société Anonyme, of which Lazzell was a member, and one folder of acceptance and rejection notices from exhibitions. regarding artwork Blanche Lazzell submitted.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically. Prominent artists and individuals with three or more letters have individual named folders. Unidentified correspondents, holiday cards, and notices about exhibition submissions are arranged at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence from W. O., Lois, Ida, Ruth, and Jameson Cain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Letters from Lois, Ida, Ruth, Jameson, and W. O. Cain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from Annie, Frank, and Mary Dwight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence from Boyce, Tallulah, and Hattie Ramsey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fragments of letters written by Blanche Lazzell with dates and names of correspondents missing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings include notebooks, essays, and notes. The bulk of the notebooks contain class notes from Lazzell's classes at West Virginia Conference Seminary and West Virginia University. There is also one notebook from Lazzell's art studies with Albert Gleizes in Paris and one notebook that tracks time spent and progress made on prints and works in progress, with some information about pricing. Essays and notes consist of school papers, handwritten and typed drafts of essays on art, biographical sketches, lists and inventories of exhibitions and artwork, and miscellaneous notes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as 2 subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly class notes, but also includes a few pages at the end of the notebook on sales of handpainted "china pins" in 1911.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a few drawings of budding branches.

did.unittitle: History of Roman and Modern Art Notebooks

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mostly school notes from 1902-1904, but also includes several pages used as a studio guest list from 1930-1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notebook is written in French, possibly from a class with Albert Gleizes, and includes several sketches.

did.unittitle: Notes on the Creativity of Children
"Creative Design" Essay on Rugs and Fabrics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes retyped excerpts from reviews of Blanche Lazzell's work along with other notes.

did.unittitle: "On a Provincetown Dock" by Mary A. Kirkup
"Metamorphic Progressions of Shape" by Stanley E. Shafer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are five bound diaries and a few loose scattered diary entries. Three of the diaries are from Lazzell's first trip to Europe from 1912 to 1913, one of which also includes entries about her second trip to Europe in 1923-1924. There is also a guidebook heavily annotated by Lazzell with information about itineraries and and locations of interest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes entries about first Europe trip and second trip from 1923-1924.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal business records consist of 3 ledgers that list Lazzell's expenses beginning in her early school years at the West Virginia Conference Seminary, and one book tracking the sales and expenses for hand-painted china.

did.unittitle: Account Book for Handpainted China Expenses and Sales

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes guestbooks of visitors to exhibitions and Lazzell's studio, news clippings, exhibition catalogs for solo and group shows, exhibition announcements, assorted magazines, brochures, newsletters, and other miscellaneous material. Most but not all of the clippings and catalogs include references to Blanche Lazzell and her art.

did.unittitle: Loose Pages from Wood Block Print Exhibition Guest Sign-In

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes catalogs for solo shows and group exhibitions that Lazzell participated in.

did.unittitle: Bulletin of the Detroit Institute of Arts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork includes pencil drawings from a class with Albert Gleizes during Lazzell's second trip to Paris in 1924. The drawings and sketches include annotations by Lazzell along with some class notes. There is also one folder of miscellaneous, undated sketches.

did.unittitle: Pencil Drawings from Albert Gleizes Class
Sketches from "The Golden Section and Mathematics in Art"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs, slides, and one lantern slide. Most of the photographs are black and white, with a few in color, and they show Blanche Lazzell with artists and friends, her Provincetown studio and harbor, artwork, and travels in Italy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The materials are grouped first by format, such as prints and slides, then by subjects in chronological order.

did.unittitle: West Virginia University Group Outing at Coopers Rock

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of Blanche Lazzell alone and accompanied by friends, a few while traveling in Italy, but mostly at outside her Provincetown studio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of the Provincetown wharf, harbor, and shore near Lazzell's studio.

did.unittitle: Artwork Photographed on Site at Provincetown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of artwork at various locations in Provincetown such as inside Lazzell's studio and at Hans Hofmann's class.

did.unittitle: Justice Mural at Courthouse in Morgantown, West Virginia
Group Photos of "Gallery 200" Artists at Provincetown
Lantern Slide of Red and White Petunia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artifacts include 2 metal signs and 1 paint palette in a metal case.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The signs are first, followed by the paint palette.
